text:
The Alamak! Awards are back!

While our AWARE Awards celebrate individuals and organisations that break the barriers of gender inequality each year, our annual Alamak! Awards have since 2011 been given out to those who have done the opposite - i.e. further entrenched sexist and patriarchal norms in Singapore.

These are the four Alamak! nominees for 2020... and we need you to help determine the winner by voting! The (un)lucky winner will be announced during our AWAREHouse Party on 28 November - but not before all four nominees are skewered in song by the wickedly funny musical satire group Chestnuts.

Get your vote in now! Visit bit.ly/32TbHju to make your pick.

text:
"Because the whole day you are awake and you also have to wake up the whole night. It is hard… In the morning I have time to rest, but I cannot sleep. I really cannot.”

Domestic workers suffer from a caregiver burden, caused by overwork, inaccurate job matching and inadequate informational/emotional support. This impairs both the workers' well-being, and the quality of care they can provide to our elderly - a lose-lose scenario.

For "Neither Family Nor Employee", a study by AWARE and HOME: Humanitarian Organisation for Migration Economics, we interviewed 25 migrant domestic workers providing eldercare in Singapore (as well as a range of employers, employment agencies and training providers).

Learn more about our findings and our recommendations in these graphics. Read the full report at bit.ly/3nidEh0.

text:
"What’s been a less-than-ideal market for Singaporeans seeking employment is a nightmare situation for foreigners here, with businesses having to meet local employee quotas and navigate other laws regarding the hiring of foreigners.

As things stand, it looks likely that Ramisa will be required to leave Singapore and return to Bangladesh in five months' time.

Though she hasn’t begun to fathom what life would be like there; 'I don’t want to imagine it,' she said."

Transnational families - many of whom have lived in Singapore for decades - are integral parts of our community. In a time of recession and travel restrictions, we ask authorities to be more compassionate to these families. The government should consider granting an automatic extension to those whose LTVPs are expiring or due for renewal during this period.

MOTHERSHIP.SG
Bangladeshi mum & daughter fight to stay together in S'pore after Covid-19 took their jobs

text:
We are proud to launch our latest research report, "Neither Family Nor Employee", alongside HOME: Humanitarian Organisation for Migration Economics. "Neither Family Nor Employee" examines the stress (or "caregiver burden") faced by migrant domestic workers caring for the elderly in Singapore.

Building upon our 2019 #MakeCareCount report on family caregivers, this qualitative study was based on interviews with 25 domestic workers providing eldercare, as well as a range of employers, employment agencies and training providers. We found that three major factors for domestic workers' caregiver burden were overwork (14.5 work hours a day on average), inaccurate job matching and inadequate informational/emotional support.

Our recommendations to ameliorate the situation include strengthening legislative protection over domestic workers' working conditions, improving categorisation of skills and care needs for better matching, expanding formal eldercare training and creating targeted support resources.

Read our full report at the link.

AWARE.ORG.SG
Migrant domestic workers caring for the elderly afflicted by overwork, inaccurate job matching and inadequate support: AWARE-HOME study

text:
Today kickstarts #16daysofactivism against gender based violence. As an organization that functions to support survivors of abuse, we have experienced the chain of reactions that gender based violence bring upon its victims. Today we invite you to pledge along with us; to never commit. To always intervene. And to never be a bystander. Silence allows violence; I won’t be silent to enable violence.

#16DaysOfActivism #genderbasedviolence #SupportSurvivors #emergestrong

text:
We are so excited for our amazing founder who will be speaking with the dynamic ladies at Simply Unique! Please mark your calendar for Saturday 5 December and learn about Alia's Emerge journey!

Simply Unique added a new photo to the album: SIMPLY ONLINE — with Alia Whitney-Johnson at Emerge Global.
November 5 at 11:30 AM ·

Simply Online is pleased to announce our second Guest Speaker.

Alia Whitney-Johnson is an experienced social entrepreneur with fifteen years of experience working with children who’ve endured trauma, sexual abuse, and exploitation.

During the summer of 2005, at the age of 19, Alia arrived in Sri Lanka as a tsunami-relief volunteer. During this trip, she encountered a heartbreaking reality: Girls as young as 11 who had survived rape or incest and had the courage to stand up for themselves in court were often cast out of their own families and placed in protective shelters away from society where they had little access to education or support.

That summer, she launched Emerge (www.emergeglobal.org) as a way to connect the girls to critical life and business skills, healing resources, and a community of support. Since then, Emerge has gone on to serve over 1,100 powerful young women.

Alia is also the Co-Founder and Executive Director of Freedom Forward (www.Freedom-Forward.org), a non-profit that is working to prevent the commercial sexual exploitation of youth in San Francisco through systems change. Through this role, she served as the Co-Chair of San Francisco’s Youth Trafficking Committee for the Mayor’s Task Force on Anti-Human Trafficking in 2017 and 2018, where she started the task force’s first Youth Advisory Board. She also helped form a collaborative of organizations to provide a full continuum of wrap-around services to youth who have or may experience commercial sexual exploitation.

Previously, Alia served as a consultant at McKinsey & Company and worked at LeanIn.org. She has served on several boards including the MIT Corporation (MIT’s board of trustees), SERES Global, Emerge Lanka Foundation, and ATHack!. Whitney-Johnson holds a B.S. in Civil and Environmental Engineering from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and an MPhil in Development Studies from the University of Oxford, where she studied as a Rhodes Scholar.

During this trip, she encountered a heartbreaking reality: Girls as young as 11 who had survived rape or incest and had the courage to stand up for themselves in court were often cast out of their own families and placed in protective shelters away from society where they had little access to education or support.

That summer, she launched Emerge (www.emergeglobal.org) as a way to connect the girls to critical life and business skills, healing resources, and a community of support. Since then, Emerge has gone on to serve over 1,100 powerful young women.

Alia is also the Co-Founder and Executive Director of Freedom Forward (www.Freedom-Forward.org), a non-profit that is working to prevent the commercial sexual exploitation of youth in San Francisco through systems change. Through this role, she served as the Co-Chair of San Francisco’s Youth Trafficking Committee for the Mayor’s Task Force on Anti-Human Trafficking in 2017 and 2018, where she started the task force’s first Youth Advisory Board. She also helped form a collaborative of organizations to provide a full continuum of wrap-around services to youth who have or may experience commercial sexual exploitation.

Whitney-Johnson holds a B.S. in Civil and Environmental Engineering from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and an MPhil in Development Studies from the University of Oxford, where she studied as a Rhodes Scholar.

text:
Our team is completed with individuals who believe in our cause to their fullest and go above and beyond to ensure that we reach higher peaks.

Meet Ashani, someone who is extremely dedicated to our cause and even more dedicated and passionate about empowering our girls. Ashani joined our team in 2017, and currently functions as our Reintegration and Admin Manager. Especially during these challenging times, Ashani has been our force of support, keeping the team grounded and positive. Soft spoken, but highly intelligent and always thinking two steps ahead, Ashani has effortlessly created some great connections for our girls, who fondly call her ‘Akki’. She’s such a loyal, trustworthy and a dependable figure in our team, committed to make a big difference in the work we do and who we do it for. We are really lucky and blessed to have Ashani in our team.

text:
At Emerge Lanka Foundation, together with our sister organisation, Emerge Global, we work with young survivors of sexual abuse. We value and encourage the young women in our programmes to heal and emerge on their own terms.

We support and advocate for body autonomy, self-determination, and the ability to be the best version of ourselves. We celebrate those who choose to stand up and honor their deepest truths - who are brave enough to claim their truth even when society challenges or harms them for these truths.

No one should be penalized, harassed, or subjected to the inhumane treatment that many members of the LGBTQI community has recently suffered. To those who have lost your freedom or suffered violence at the hands of others, we see you.

We condemn the violence recently taken against the LGBTQI community in Sri Lanka.

To the LGBTQI community, we stand with you and for you. Today, and every day.

Aritha Wickramasinghe
October 30 at 5:05 AM ·

Judicial Medical Officers and #Police have been exposed conducting forced #anal and #vaginal examinations on #LGBT Sri Lankans. These exams are done to “prove” #homosexuality and to use as evidence to prosecute LGBT people.

These exams are degrading, cruel and amounts to torture. They have been banned by world bodies including the World Health Organization (WHO) and World Medical Association - WMA. The Sri Lanka Medical Association and Sri Lanka Medical Council are yet to issue any statement condemning these cruel exams. There is no requirement in law to conduct them and the #JusticeMinistry must request all their #JMOs to stop conducting them. The #AttorneyGeneral must also direct all Police to stop arresting and harassing #LGBT people.

In one case the JMO put two of his fingers inside the vaginas of both a #transgenderman and a cis #woman asked them if it hurt. They were also subject to more physical examinations in front of other male nurses and doctors. When they pleaded with the doctor not to insert his fingers inside again, the doctor said that he will light a firecracker next.

It is ironic that the Police want to #prosecute LGBT people for consensual relationships by getting doctors to forcefully probe our anus’ and vaginas with their fingers. It’s very clear here who has committed the offence, and it’s not us! Only perverts order and conduct these exams.

Great work by Daily Mirror in exposing these practices and violations. We can only hope for justice for LGBT people and the victims of these examinations.

#Equality #lovewillwin #lovewins

http://www.dailymirror.lk/news-features/JMOs-and-Police-conducting-forced-anal-and-vaginal-examinations-on-LGBT-people/131-198911

text:
Daily progress adding up to big victories.

All our participants enrolled in the beads-to-business program learn the basics of jewelry creation by creating these short necklaces; it’s the first step to practicing the art of beading to master the skills that goes into creating their own masterpiece.

Since our programs are self paced, we encourage them to take their time learning this well, so that they can create beautiful, high quality pieces of jewelry that act as their own avenue of income.

Simply Unique is with Shalini Fernando at Emerge Global.
October 23 at 9:25 AM ·

We will be talking about:

1. The work Emerge does in Sri Lanka regarding survivors of underaged rape

2. The short term and long term Impacts of Institutionalisation

3. The social stigma surrounding underaged rape victims

Tune in to our live chat tomorrow at 6:30pm Colombo, Sri Lanka time.

These lovely ladies will speak for 30mins and take as many of your questions as possible.

text:
In our avenue of work having supportive, kind and self-reflecting Program Officers make all the difference for our girls to be inspired to push further.

Suzanne is one such mentor that we've been lucky to have on our side since March this year. Suzanne joined us with experience in teaching children of all ages for over 23 years. Naturally motivated with the greatest attitude any educator can have, Suzanne is always encouraging those around her with a jolly mood. It didn't take us too long to fall in love with her when she came bearing loads of love. Suzanne's great listening skills, her undying empathy and her love to learn and improve her own skills have proven to be a blessing to our girls especially during this very challenging year. Today and everyday, we celebrate Suzanne and her vibrant and inspiring personality for joining hands with us to strive for a change in our world.

text:
Dhammika is one of our Centre Mother's who shoulders the responsibility of caring for the girls under our care. Her gentle, kind and empathetic personality makes her a strong mother figure to our girls who've gone through many challenges in their lives. Passionately dedicated to the Emerge mission, Dhammika always has a story to draw inspiration and strength from. Our girls lovingly call her Amma; for her kindness and always lending an attentive ear to all their concerns.

Dhammika is not only a strength to the Emerge girls, but for all of us, who rest assured whenever she takes on any responsibility.

text: We invite our community to take a stand against child sexual abuse. Our voice is our biggest power
post_text: let’s use it responsibly to bring change to our children at risk.
shared_text: We invite our community to take a stand against child sexual abuse. Our voice is our biggest power
time: let’s use it responsibly to bring change to our children at risk.

text:
Aritha Wickramasinghe
July 18 at 3:31 PM ·

In the last 24 hours, 3 girl children were brutally #raped and #killed in Sri Lanka! Most of the accused are young men below the age of 30.

Child sexual abuse and rape is endemic in #SriLanka with the police, courts and education authorities still doing very little to stem the problem.

The average rape case takes 14 years in Sri Lanka with only 1 rape conviction in 2018.

What kind of men are coming out of our schools? What exactly are our schools teaching them for them to be raping and killing young baby girls?

In 2019, the then Government withdrew an age appropriate #sexeducation book for children because of some made up cultural sensitivity.

In 2018, the members of the present Sri Lankan Government, while in opposition, falsely accused Think Equal of trying to spread #homosexuality to young children.

#ThinkEqual was actually teaching children values such as #respect, #kindness and #compassion. The programme was created out of the need to end violence against women following the brutal gang rape of a medical student in a bus in Delhi.

The failures by our political leaders to address these issues and their active participation to prevent solutions make them responsible for the crimes against these girls.

Where is the justice for our girls and women?

text:
Our Senior Program Officer Nirukshi, or as fondly called ‘Niru Amma’ by our girls, have been with us since our beginning 13 years ago. A uniquely creative individual, she loves anything colorful and quirky. This is why she’s the ideal person to guide our girls with their Beads to Business creations, helping the girls with creative color matching and being the strength they seek.

One of our favorite things about Nirukshi is how committed she is to our girls. She always makes sure to write small notes of encouragement to show them how loved and appreciated they are in our community. Nirukshi, thank you for all that you do; we are grateful to have you as a part of our team.

text:
This Wednesday marks the start of the #16DaysOfActivism to #EndGenderBasedViolence - a time for global action to increase awareness and galvanize advocacy on behalf of women, girls, and marginalized genders.

To build a world free of gender-based violence it is no longer possible to only rely on the grassroots activists who dedicate their lives to doing this work, we must all play our part. Are you in?

#OrangeTheWorld

EQUALITYNOW.ORG

To build a world free of gender-based violence it is no longer possible to only rely on the grassroots activists who dedicate their lives to doing this work, we must all play our part. Are you in?

text:
We’re SO CLOSE to a new anti-FGM law in the United States! In September, the U.S. House of Representatives passed the Stop FGM Act of 2020, and it was then referred to the Senate Committee on the Judiciary. The bill has the full support of the Department of Justice. All the Judiciary Committee chairs need to do is bring it out of committee for a vote on the Senate Floor.

The Senate session will end within the next two weeks, which doesn’t leave much time for a vote - but it CAN happen. And it MUST: if the Stop FGM Act of 2020 doesn’t get passed this year, supporters will have to start all over again from scratch next year with the new Congress.

Please join us in calling on the Judiciary Committee to protect women and girls from FGM in the U.S. today!

https://www.equalitynow.org/us_protect_women_and_girls_from_female_genital_mutilation_fgm

EQUALITYNOW.ORG
United States: Protect women and girls from Female Genital Mutilation (FGM)

text:
Along with six other women in Georgia, I’m sharing my story of escaping child marriage.

Three years on and I am defining my own future. I know my rights, and I will continue to fight for them. I will continue to campaign to end child marriage.

I want parents to know the importance of listening to their children, and centering their happiness.

I want girls and women across Georgia to know they have rights, and that there is support out there if they need it.

Read our stories in 'Courage: Survivors of child marriage in Georgia share their stories' at equalitynow.org/courage_georgia

text:
Whilst child marriage and forced marriage are against the law in Georgia, a 2018 UNICEF report found that among women aged 20-24, 14% were married by the age of 18 in Georgia. The Ministry of the Interior of Georgia has recorded 34 cases of bride kidnapping in the first 9 months of 2020. In Courage, released by Goga Khatiashvili and Equality Now, seven women, forced to marry as children, tell their stories.

Dedicated to everyone who speaks up about violence, the publication serves as a reminder to us all that girls and women have the right to live free from violence.

#EndChildMarriage #ListenToSurvivors

EQUALITYNOW.ORG
Courage: Survivors of child marriage in Georgia share their stories

text:
Equality Now is saddened to hear that Vanessa Kogan, a prominent human rights activist and Director of the Justice Initiative project (Проект "Правовая инициатива") in Russia, faces expulsion from the country. She has been given two weeks to leave Russia, after her residence permit was revoked on December 2.

"Today I learned that 11 years of living in Russia, 2 children born in the Russian Federation with Russian citizenship, 11 years of paid taxes are not enough to be considered “our own”. On the contrary, you can just take everything and tear it off in an instant: the residence permit is canceled, 2 weeks to leave the country”, wrote Vanessa on her Facebook.

Justice Initiative has been operating in Russia since 2001 and the project provides legal support to Russian citizens seeking justice for human rights abuses in both local courts and the European Court of Human Rights in Strasbourg. Justice Initiative also works in Russia’s North Caucasus, documenting abuses by law enforcement and the military, and gender discrimination. The project presented the case of Valeria Volodina to the ECHR, according to which the Strasbourg Court in 2019 issued the first ruling on domestic violence in Russia.

We stand in solidarity with Vanessa and urge the Russian authorities to immediately annul this decision.

#WHRD #HumanRightsDefenders #16DaysOfActivism #16Days

THEGUARDIAN.COM
Russia moves to expel American human rights activist

text:
Ahead of #GivingTuesday, we've been thinking about the world we want to live in. It's a world where:

🧡 Every woman and girl knows her rights
🧡 Survivors of violence are able to voice their concerns without fear of stigma or belief
🧡 Justice systems work for women and girls, not against them
🧡 Survivors are able to access support services that are centered around their needs
🧡 Survivors are empowered to move forward with agency

The work ahead of us will take more than #16Days, but we aren't cowed. Ahead of #GivingTuesday2020 donate whatever you can to support our work to #MakeEqualityReality.

www.equalitynow.org/donate

text:
2020 has been a year like no other, with the continued rise of authoritarianism, police brutality against Black men and women, and the rollback of human rights, and women’s rights in particular. There have been continued attempts to silence women human rights defenders across the world from Iran to Zimbabwe.

This International Women Human Rights Defenders Day, learn more about some of the women and organizations on the frontlines of the movement to protect and promote human rights across the world, including:

👉 Azza Soliman, co-founder of مؤسسة قضايا المرأة المصرية - Centre for Egyptian Women Legal Assistance,
👉 Dina Smailova, Head of Kazakh women's rights organization Немолчиkz,
👉 Loujain alHathloul and other detained #SaudiWomen,
👉 Dalit activists Manjula Pradeep and Manisha Mashaal, founder of Swabhiman society,
👉 Puerto Rican organization Proyecto Matria
👉 the migrant women who went public about forced sterilizations in immigration detention in the United States, and
👉 Zimbabwean women Joanna Mamombe, Cecilia Chimbiri, and Netsai Marova.

#16DaysOfActivism #OrangeTheWorld #HumanRightsDefenders

EQUALITYNOW.ORG
International Women Human Rights Defenders Day 2020: The women working to make equality reality

text:
Caste-based sexual violence is being used as a weapon to oppress Dalit women, capitalizing on gendered power dynamics to maintain caste hierarchies across the country.

These hierarchies are used to silence Dalit women and girls through threats and a consistent failure by the police to register complaints by survivors, resulting in a culture of “violence, silence, and impunity”.

Read more about our latest report, released in partnership with Swabhiman society, in The Swaddle.

#EndCasteBasedSexualViolence #HaryanaDalitWomenSpeakOut #16DaysOfActivism

THESWADDLE.COM
Oppressor-Caste Solidarity Drives Culture of Silence Around Rapes of Dalit Girls in Haryana: Report

text:
The recent Hathras case is just one example of the widespread sexual violence taking place against Dalit women and girls across India.

Our new report, launched together with Swabhiman society, found Dalit survivors of sexual violence in Haryana, are facing severe obstacles to accessing justice as well as intersectional caste and gender discrimination.

The time is now to end caste based sexual violence, and it’s on all of us. Will you join us in calling on the Haryana State Government to end sexual violence and caste based discrimination? Every voice counts.

#HaryanaDalitWomenSpeakOut #EndCasteBasedSexualViolence #16DaysofActivism

EQUALITYNOW.ORG
India: Haryana Government must act to end caste-based sexual violence

text:
Brisa de Angulo didn’t get justice when she was raped as a teen. She endured three trials in Bolivia, but her rapist has yet to be held accountable for any of his crimes. In 2012, Brisa filed a case before the Inter-American Commission of Human Rights, who referred it to the Inter-American Court of Human Rights this past August 7th, 2020. Today, Equality Now and the rest of Brisa's legal team officially filed the brief for Brisa’s case before the Court, with the hearing expected in 2021. Now, almost 20 years after her ordeal started, her case could set a legal precedent in Bolivia and for the Americas which all member States would be held to, improving the lives of girls and women throughout the Western Hemisphere.

EQUALITYNOW.ORG
An Important Step Toward Accountability for Sexual Violence in Bolivia and Beyond

text:
Two years ago, Imani* was raped by her neighbor and became pregnant as a result. She was 16 at the time and in primary school back in Moshi, Tanzania.

Imani loved sciences and geography and wanted to work as a doctor or a nurse when she completed her studies.

Imani represents tens of thousands of adolescent school-going girls in Tanzania who can longer access education owing to the ban prohibiting pregnant girls and teenage mothers from attending school.

And despite numerous efforts urging Tanzania to lift the ban, lack of political will has been a great obstacle.

We, in collaboration with our partners, have therefore today filed a case against Tanzania at the African Court on Human and People’s Rights in Arusha to challenge this policy and have it lifted.

We stand with Imani and every other girl that she represents. Do you?

Share this post to demand that Tanzania #LetGirlsLearn and read more about the filing on our website ➡️ https://bit.ly/2ITDn0B

#EndSexualViolence #WaacheMabintiWasome #WorldChildrensDay #WorldChildrensDay2020 #GirlsRights #GirlsEducation

EQUALITYNOW.ORG
Court case filed against Tanzania to overturn ban on pregnant girls attending school
post_text:
Two years ago, Imani* was raped by her neighbor and became pregnant as a result. She was 16 at the time and in primary school back in Moshi, Tanzania.

Imani loved sciences and geography and wanted to work as a doctor or a nurse when she completed her studies.

Imani represents tens of thousands of adolescent school-going girls in Tanzania who can longer access education owing to the ban prohibiting pregnant girls and teenage mothers from attending school.

And despite numerous efforts urging Tanzania to lift the ban, lack of political will has been a great obstacle.

We, in collaboration with our partners, have therefore today filed a case against Tanzania at the African Court on Human and People’s Rights in Arusha to challenge this policy and have it lifted.

We stand with Imani and every other girl that she represents. Do you?

Share this post to demand that Tanzania #LetGirlsLearn and read more about the filing on our website ➡️ https://bit.ly/2ITDn0B

#EndSexualViolence #WaacheMabintiWasome #WorldChildrensDay #WorldChildrensDay2020 #GirlsRights #GirlsEducation

text:
An analysis of Kuwait’s Penal Code released today by Equality Now and Abolish Article 153, reveals the extent to which Kuwait’s laws are failing to protect women and girls:

➡️ Article 182 allows rapists to escape punishment by marrying the woman or girl they raped, a provision actively condones and rewards sexual violence

➡️ Article 153 provides a lenient sentence for a man who kills his female relatives, a provision rooted in valuing ‘honor’ over the human rights of women and girls;

➡️ the Penal Code does not explicitly criminalize marital rape, leaving women vulnerable to sexual violence committed with impunity

➡️ and the definition of rape is reliant on the use of force, threats or deception rather than being grounded in consent.

It’s time to abolish laws that see women and girls as vessels of their family’s honor, and build an equal world that works for our mothers, our sisters, our daughters, our friends, our communities. Join Kuwaiti activists calling for reform today.

#EndSexualViolence #MarryYourRapist

EQUALITYNOW.ORG
Justice over honor: Kuwait should amend its Penal Code to protect women and girls from sexual violence

text:
Due to #COVID19, 13 million more girls are at risk of #ChildMarriage, and 2 million more could undergo female genital mutilation by 2030. We can't let this happen.

Today we are joining with Girls Not Brides: The Global Partnership to End Child Marriage and the Global Platform for Action to End FGM/C to call on the leaders of the #GenerationEquality Actions Coalition on Gender-Based Violence to commit to ending
#FGM and child, early and forced marriage (CEFM).

Sign this open letter and call on leaders to ensure girls are free to decide their futures.

English ➡️ https://bit.ly/LetterEng
Español ➡️ https://bit.ly/LetterEsp
Français ➡️ https://bit.ly/LetterFra

text:
While child marriage has risen during the pandemic, the virus did not create societal conditions that judged a girl’s worth on her ability to be a wife.

While domestic care-workers have been unable to receive paid sick leave, it did not create an economy that devalued reproductive labor.

While government relief packages have excluded refugees and undocumented immigrants, it did not create political institutions that preferenced the powerful and privileged at the expense of the marginalized.

But what it did do, was force the world to acknowledge that women and girls continue to face both sex and gender-based discrimination. Read more about why we can't let this opportunity to define a new, inclusive future pass us by. ⬇️

EQUALITYNOW.ORG
2020 has been a year like no other, 2021 must be the year we change the game

text:
This is from a piece I wrote 6 years ago after the murder of Michael Brown - Why Black Lives Should Matter to the Anti-Trafficking Movement. Don’t have new words right now. Black Lives Matter.

“The truth is that you can’t claim to be ‘anti-trafficking’ and not be anti-racism. Being anti-racist doesn’t just mean not saying the ‘n’ word or telling racist jokes. It means that you have to actively be engaged as an ally, question your own privilege and address all the subtle and not so subtle ways that structural racism interacts with your life.

You can’t say you care about trafficking victims of color, but not take a moment to understand how race impacts their lives. You can’t talk about prevention of commercial sexual exploitation without addressing poverty and how race and class are inextricably linked in this country. You can’t talk about options for survivors and ‘aftercare’ without acknowledging that those options look different for different survivors. You can’t sit quietly by on the sidelines because all this talk about race makes you uncomfortable. And you can’t pick and choose your social justice issues like you’re at a buffet bar.

All of this is linked, all of it is interconnected and all of this is indeed related to commercial sexual exploitation and trafficking, in all of its forms. As a movement with momentum and interest and a huge amount of support right now, we need to ensure that we’re a movement that is headed in the right direction on all issues of equality and justice, and we need to leverage that momentum to create real, lasting change. Black lives matter, and its past the time for the anti-trafficking movement to send that message loud and clear.”

#blacklivesmatter
#georgeflloydmatters
#breonnataylormatters
#ahmaudarberymatters
